column11: Review Text

column8: Real Indiana Jones Feeling: sunken temple in the jungle
column11: Still an insider tip. Here you can play Indiana Jones in search of the temple lost in the jungle. For a few rupees, the guard comes downstairs at the entrance and shows you the extensive complex. It goes uphill, but on cobbled paths, you pass huge Java Almond trees with board roots, behind which a whole family fits.
Nice walk in the forest. I think the guide is a plus otherwise we don't have too much history of the site and after that just remains ruins üòâ After not many people, it remains appreciable

First of all, you should know that the walk is long and includes hundreds of steps. But the effort is not rewarded. There is absolutely nothing to do with it. Ruins are worse than ruins, there are only a few scattered stones. The restoration is non-existent, there is no maintenance. Vegetation is anything. Move around, nothing to see.

column8: The serenity of the area is incredibly calming
column11: I took a scooter ride with Kingsley to the monastery, which was great fun. Once there, the tour was an amazing history lesson of the Buddhist way of life so many years ago. It's a lot of uphill and downhill walking, so wear comfy walking shoes. The tour ended with a 30 minute yoga session with Kingsley where I felt so relaxed afterwards and grateful for the experience.

Very interesting old forest monastery in very quiet and fascinating nature. We had a very good guide who studied archaeology and gave us a lot of information about the lives of the monks. Likewise the importance of the steps on the various levels with philosophical stories on them. We really enjoyed it and are worth a visit who is interested in Buddhist history.
Old temple which were used to live more than 10,000 monks in earlier. Guiders will come with you. Ticket prices also very low.

column8: Desolate ruins, although ruins is an exaggeration.
column11: I didn't like this pile of rubble at all. Just broken stones. And then the highlight: a tree in the middle of nowhere. A tree. No explanation of the story. Not worth it.

column8: Peaceful and serene Sri Lanka moment
column11: Out of the tourism path, if you have a good guides you will be able to see the best of this ancient city and understand how great this place was.  Very peaceful with century trees all around, I advised it in your way to Sigirya

Ritigala Nature Reserve is a hidden gem waiting to be explored. With its tranquil atmosphere, ancient ruins, and diverse flora and fauna, it offers a unique experience for nature enthusiasts and history buffs alike. Don't miss the chance to hike through lush forests, discover ancient Buddhist monasteries, and immerse yourself in the serenity of this mystical place. Highly recommend for a memorable adventure off the beaten path.

Really interesting (not a ‚Äòtourist attraction‚Äô more a historical archeological site) be prepared however for a reasonable climb up to the big tree. Wear decent shoes and take water. There‚Äôs a $5 entrance fee per person and a tuk tuk from Habarana with the driver waiting for you to go up and down (1.5hrs approx) will cost approx 4/5,000 Sri Lankan rupee (2024). Round trip around 3.5hrs

Ritigala, between Anuradhapaura and Kandy, are monastery ruins located in the jungle. The visit was one of our highlights in Sri Lanka. Beautiful walks on small paths in the jungle and then you keep coming across remains that are more than a thousand years old. There are few other visitors, wonderfully quiet! The last kilometers to the entrance are not possible with a normal car (taxi), because there are many holes in the road. Our guide/driver had comfortably rented a jeep with driver, but a tuc tuc is also possible. Highly recommended to hire a local guide at the entrance, 2000 rupees, then you will learn so much more.

So 1850 rupees or x 6 in 5 years... well done... Friendly and quiet Except the mosquitoes who had fun with me 2 hours round trip wet ride And the staff who sweep the path... Lost deep in the forest. Great view at bridge number 2

Exploring the archaeological remains of the Buddhist monastery in Ritigala on your own using a map (entrance fee $6) is possible, but you might miss out on a richer experience. Initially planning to do so ourselves, we fortunately encountered Daya, a guide with over 20 years of experience. Thanks to him, we discovered hidden spots not evident on the map. His engaging commentary provided us with many fascinating insights into this breathtaking site, constructed over 2300 years ago. I highly recommend it.

A wonderful walk through an area full of trees and all kinds of plants, full of peace and tranquility, beautiful ruins, with a huge pool of several hectares, but how well some of them lived in those distant times...

WOW what a fabulous place to visit.  We were using Navin Lanka Tours (who was fabulous) and my husband really wanted to add this to the agenda and it was well worth it. There was something quite peaceful about the place and you just felt so relaxed.  Amazing HUGE tree also which was just awesome. Highly recommend a visit as not very busy (very cheap too) and very tranquil.

Literally a jungle path of steps to nothing except a few badly decayed columns every so often. Each level looked the same and I also had no idea what anything was. We got to the 'top', which was a tree and assumed there was more - but no. It was a tree. So basically a collection of unexplained stone pillars in the middle of a boiling jungle that you have to sweat your ass off to reach the top which is a whole load of nothing not even anymore columns!  (instead a tree, some bracken and a fence stopping you going any further)
It is a wonderful ancient  place of Sri Lanka. It is difficult to believe those ruins are made by humans.

This is not on the regular tourist list but I had read about it and asked our driver to take us from sigirya. Took about an hour and 1 /4. The last bit of road (2k) is unmade but driveable in a van. We got there at about 8.30 am.  We took a local guide as not much written about this place. We had to walk for about 1.5 hours through some jungle but mostly uncovered archeological walkway. 1080 lkr entry fee. 2000 lkr for the guide.  He didn't ask for that but we felt he was worth it. I am so glad I have seen this. It is an amazing place.  Not commercialized yet. Very few tourists. They are still uncovering parts of the site.  I have a bad knee but managed the walk. Guide and husband assisted on long flights of steps.

This is one of the strict natural reserves (‡∂Ö‡∂∞‡∑í ‡∂ª‡∂ö‡∑ä‡∑Ç‡∑í‡∂≠) in the country with multiple climates as you trail. It has been the home to an ancient Buddhist Monastery that dates back to 1st century BCE. Ritigala mountain covers over 3,500 acres and stands above over 2,500 sea level. It also contains a number of endemic trees where some of them are found only within this forest. Since it is classified as a strict natural reserve, entry to some of the areas are carefully governed and restricted. In addition to the natural beauty, greenery and the "one of a kind" experience, what we see today are the remains of the structures of the Monastery.

it has the largest man made pond, build exclusively for buddhist monk, exceptional architectural design, view from the library was amazing, the rationale to build the library at such a location was outstanding, the toilets, ruins of loo, the technology used back in the day is amazing to learn, it has some of the rarest / tallest trees in the country, the hike was amazing, much better than a usual botanical garden walk, Tip: Take a guide who is from that area, it will be rather boring experience without the guide, it's interesting to learn the history as you explore this monastery.

Ritigala Buddhist forest monastery is situated 55 kms away from waterfront home stay in anuradhapura. It is not a rain forest but it has all the elements a rain forest has. It is believed to be built in 820AD  (completion )by a king called "sena "with Marshaling nearly 1000 people who was known as the devil clan  (yakka gothrika people ).the ritigala Buddhist forest monastery is the oldest Buddhist forest monastery in Sri Lanka. It contains a main hall, meditation complex, library, hospital complex and meditation path. There are several myth stories about ritigala. One is there lived a man called ritigala jayasena and he engage with a huge battle with a war hero called gotayimbara the giant hero of King dutu gamunu, in the end of the fight jayasena looses his head and it disappeared in the forest. The villagers search for his head and found a head of a bear and fixed it to jayasena's body but keeping his face backwards. People were frustrated with seen him and he eventually called there in after as a goast  (mahasona ).the other myth story is that a battle between the two kings called rama and rawana. In the battlefield the ramas brother got wounded. Rama had to call for hanuman  (hanumantha )to bring medicine from a mountain of himalayas in India. The hanuman couldn't find any medicine bring a part of the himalayas mountain by air. Two parts of the mountain collapsed in the air one part drop at RITIGALA and other part drop at ROOMASSALA in down south. Even today you can see many plants in ritigala which can be only seen in himalayas in India. If you visit anuradhapura you must see this beautiful place. Just ask your hotel manager to arrange it.

Unesco Site an ongoing archaelogical dig. Very interesting. Bit of a clinb to get to main building over rocks and streams but worth the effort. The viewes for the Library was great.plenty of trees and plants, very restful place.
Most mysterious place in Sri Lanka with a written history of more than 2000 yrs and folklore history going upto several thousand yrs .

A fantastic walk through unspoiled forest with lots of wildlife. The remains of a nearly two thousand year old monastery dot the hillside. Beautiful environment and very peaceful. Walk tales about 1.5 hrs.  Ensure you have mosquito spray if bites trouble you

This site is perfect for travellers who wants a non-touristic experience. There are no signs and it's not all that easy to find the right way on your own. We almost missed out on most of the fun, because we couldn't seem to find the track, but luckily a guide saw us and guided us around, which included a exciting walk in the forest. The trees there are so beautiful! Don't miss out on this!

This is an awesome historical monastery the hike up was fantastic. The hike is mostly on the rock bad cut when the monastery was active. There are steps and most of the time it is at upward in Klein which is mild in natureThe hike I must say it was pretty easy other than for the incline. There are areas of the monastery still intact which would include areas of meditation and also completely intact bathrooms that were used 1000 years ago. It has a fantastic view from the top of the mountain. There is also a 3 acre lake at the bottom which is in disrepair but it is been rehabilitated by the Department of archaeology. I  used  the services of a guide and he was A fountain of knowledge as he knew the history of the monastery and also combined it with the history of Buddhism in that area. I have never met a guide  who so enjoyed his job and knew so much so I decided to include his name and telephone number if anyone is interested. His name is Asanka 0719560633. I would strongly recommend this hike.

Visited Ritigala ancient monastery and a site of a hospital where evidence of well maintained ayurvedic type, herbal treatment Centre was available. We can be a proud nation with the evidence available of using hygienic toilet facilities and the level of herbal treatments given at an era where one cannot imagine the levels. The ruins are worth seeing, and the use of natural resources such as water, nature plants, flowers, bark, roots and fruits were used for the medications with such high values. The huge pond, is nice to note that water was not just allowed to flow to the rivers and seas without any use. The engineering knowledge used is un imaginable and can be proud of the nation. The preserving efforts are very good to note and and happy that the visitors have not ruined the place with their plastics and rubbish. Hope the authorities will take precautions to protect the place with plastic and rubbish invadors and will educate them to avoid the mismuses as well
The place and its history will have you thinking all day long The great architecture and construction they used back in the day can never ever be matched to this day!! Must visit.

A nice walk through the forest exploring the old monastery. We were the only ones there - apart from a small group of buddhist monks, and the monkeys. There is restoration going on at the beginning of the walk and there is a small charge to enter.

This place was a rare experience of our trip in Sri Lanka. If you had enough of overcrowded spots and noise, add this monastery to your visit. It is an easy walk on the path through the forest. Silence and mistery will accompany you. It takes approx 1 hour. Go over the last ruins for few meters and you will also see a giant and spectacular tree. From the main road, you have to driver for approx 15 min to reach by car.

Hidden away up a 3 km dirt road, Ritigala Forest Monastery is a fascinating, beautiful and stimulating place to visit. Make sure you get an official guide - Daya was ours - who charge around 1500SLR on top of the 350SLR entrance fee, as he'll give you insights into the rich history of this area, with its incredibly developed culture and brilliant design. It makes you re-think the uniqueness of the Romans, although most of Ritigala is 8th century, so a little later than the best of the Roman empire in Europe. Their skill in building and the beautiful little details - the feet carved in the stone marking where to stand on the urinal, for instance - reveal a deep and rich Buddhist culture which was fed by the beauty and rhythms of nature all around. Fabulous visit, totally worthwhile; I'm afraid I found Dambulla commercial and disappointing, but Ritigala helped me to forget!

I‚Äôm so glad we checked this place out. Never knew it existed and the ruins are full of grandeur. We only checked out the ruins and not the monastery. A bit difficulty climb with small kids, we only managed it because it was a large group. Please check this place out. Well worth your time.

Such a great find and so happy that we visited. The walks through the jungle are peaceful and like something out of an explorer‚Äôs adventure. We followed the paths and saw ruins from 200 BC and a few monkeys too! Would be useful to have more signs and explanations of sites.

It‚Äôs an awesome experience to walk in the paths through this jungle. You will completely forget that you are in the dry region of the country. Once you turned from the habarana Anuradhapura main road towards ritigala you‚Äôll feel the difference. The road runs through thick forest and view around is amazing. Elephants do roam around this road at evening and you can see their dung also at the road side. That‚Äôs why they close the entrance at 4pm. Final 3km is on a gravel road but easily drivable by any type of vehicle. Ancient ruins and pathways will give you a feeling of a relic hunter. You should spend good 2 3 hours here. Don‚Äôt leave your shutters open as there are monkeys everywhere and they do enter vehicle to search for food. You have to buy a ticket to enter which is only 20rs for locals. Must visit if you happen to be traveling dambulla habarana area.
You won't feel tired of walking in the Ritigala Forest Monastery as it's just worth visiting and seen the true talents & technologies that had been used by our ancestors.

We are on a tour and our driver suggested this ancient monastery as a place worth visiting - it was fantastic - the history is incredible.  Our driver also suggest that we should get a local guide - we paid 1000rp for 4 of us - it‚Äôs a tip.  So worth it his knowledge of the area and the wonderful things he told us.  I highly recommend getting off the main road and visiting this place.

Off the beaten track and can be overlooked by tourists but well worth going Bush to see this gem. It just keeps going and going and artifacts remain sprinkled around the site so you can see the functionality of each space. Do yourself a favour and hire a local guide.  Not only will they explain to you,  they will also show you so much more than you would find on your own. Especially the toilet system!!!

This was a nice quiet walk and a lot has been done to restore the ruins. The first section, a partially restored bathing tank is really large. Then you follow the track uphill. Off the path you can see evidence of the unrestored sections. We didn‚Äôt take a guide as we read online that little is actually known about what the different parts of the monastery were used for. An online search gave us enough information so we knew what we were looking at. I wouldn‚Äôt go out of my way to visit but a good option if you are in the general cultural triangle area. We paid $2 US for an adult and $1 US for a child over 6. A map is at the ticket counter which we took a picture of as a guide.
You need to know where to go to find this place. You are walking through the ‚Äújungle‚Äù stepping up to the monastery ruins. It is different to usual temples in Sri Lanka.

Our family visited this site after a recommendation by our driver and it proved to be one of the highlights of our month long trip around Sri Lanka. We arrived at the site around 330pm and despite being one of the hottest Aprils on record, the forest provides natural shade, so you can always head to Sigiriya early in the morning as we did and then Ritigala in the afternoon once you've had lunch and a rest. You are provided a plan of the site when you buy your tickets, but a guide is recommended as several paths are quite hidden and there's a point at which you are forbidden to stumble into without prior permission and protection. The higher forest contains leopards, bears and elephants are never far away. That said we were still treated to plenty of wildlife around the ruins with the monkeys being our kids favourite. We heard this site is like your own personal Indiana Jones adventure and we could see why as we had the forest all to ourselves away from the tourists. There is a tranquility about Ritigala, which we simply didn't experience anywhere else in Sri Lanka as the mysterious ruins emerge in hidden pockets around the forest. A fantastic experience, we hope to one day revisit.

This is a must visit place to all Foreigners and Sri Lankans alike. place is full of history we should know about, hence its advisable to go with a Guide who will explain all the historical values of this magnificent area.  a very very low fee is charged from locals and Foreigners which should be definitely re visited by the Authority considering the current rates charged by other sites. the pond area is under construction, better if the authorities can expedite this so that it will really add value to the visitors at the outset.

Ritigala is a strict natural reserve in Sri Lanka. There was an ancient Buddhist monastery within the forest. Ritigala mountain range consists of four peaks. The highest peak at the south of the range is called Ritigala Mountain.

It is a peaceful walk. We got a chance to see a group of amazing ruins in a calm and quiet jungle. Its a small hike but it‚Äôs really worth doing. Highly recommend this place for the people who are really interested in ancient history in Sri Lanka.
very close to where we stayed and hotel arranged our visit,. a lot of climbing till the top but it was very comfortable climb and worth visiting,.

We visited this place in early afternoon. This mountain range consists of four peaks of which the main one is called Ritigala Kanda. Monks used to pray at various levels based on the degree of meditation they carried out. There are four courtyards. It's a good walk of 1 1/2 hrs and people must wear decent walking shoes. Be prepared for occasional shower.

We visited here after walking all day in Anuradhapura which was probably a mistake as there is quite a climb.  We arrived an hour before closing and were amazed to see how many people were still there, having heard it's off the tourist trail.  However, after 10 minutes the school parties had cleared and we had the forest much to ourselves. Previous reviews basically say it all, however, on reaching the top ruin keep walking about 50 metres an there is the most beautiful tree.  Wish we had longer to explore the woods.

It is a little hard to get there because the road is not good, but is is worth it. Its a very peaceful forrest with a not too lang path through it. You don't see much animals there except monkeys, but some ruins and a nice forrest. The entry was 400 rupees, but we read about staff tryibg to trick you, so be careful.

This wander through the ruins of Ritigala Monastery was a real highlight . We went quite early in the day with no one else about and this added to the serene atmosphere. Our guide was able to give us information on the various sites we came across and we really appreciated both the historical nature of the place along with its natural beauty.

Pleasant walk through the forest, very quiet and sadly we did not see any orchids and heard very few birds that the tour operator had promised! The history of the monastery was interesting although we were allowed to see the monks in their current environment

After visiting the  crowded Lion Rock the next day we came to this site - 5 visiting cars vs 500 - why? this is a magnificent well restored very historical ruin on a massive scale out in the jungle. I think one reason it's not visited is that too many people want to  "Do" S-L in 2 weeks and therefore haven't got time to visit the lesser know sites. But if you have got time you should visit. Lion rock wont take you all day, and you can come here in the afternoon rather than visiting the Tourist Trap shops

There are many Monasteries in Sri Lanka. This is one of them in north side of the country. If you are interested in a religious tour inside a thick jungle. then visit. Nothing special to see. Human beings who are trying to develop above the intellect and who are above intellect live in this.

For less than 2000/= we rented a scooter at Habarana and followed the directions to Ritigala (bascilly the A11). Right at the 14km mark, you have to turn right. It's a scenic ride along sunlit meadows of lush rice fields and through dark patches of jungle where the road is lined with giant trees. We strolled through the magnificent ancient ruins, climbed the roughly-hewn stairs just to discover a small waterfall. We really enjoyed the spectacular feeling of a sunken city secluded in the jungle. Don't miss the old library, there is a stunning view across the jungle. We sat down and listened to the sounds of the monkeys and elephants while the sun slowly went down and the sky turned into an flaming orange. Magical. It's a lovely, easy 1,5 hours uphill walk. Ditch the flip-flops in favor of comfortable shoes, pack a bottle of water and jump right into this adventure. The fee is 2$. For 10$ you can hire a guide at the entrance. Beware of the monkeys, they might look cute - but they will steal your food!

On arrival we were immediately accosted by an 'official' guide. When I told him that we did not require a guide he was saying that we must have one as there are snakes and bears in the area. I watched quite a few Sri Lankan people set off without a guide so I again refused and they said it was up to me. We went on our own and had a nice time talking to locals and other tourists. It is fine go alone and I don't like the scare tactics they use.

Seen Ritigala several times when we were travelling back from Polonnaruwa. Out of curiosity just by the awesome looks of the mountains, we planned to visit the place someday near future. Got the chance this time and it was a really nice experience. The forest covering the ruins is one of the most beautiful I have seen in the country. I was mesmerized  by its serenity and tranquility. Also the ruins there are a great example of a well developed advanced civilization dated back 2000 years. The ruins of the huge pond the hospital there provide clear evidence for that.

We spent a very interesting half day hiking up the mountain through the monastery ruins.  The hike was great and getting history of the monestaries gave us better insight inot other aspects of what we were seeing in the Cultural Triangle.  We used a guide, Manjoo provided by Sri Lanka in Style tours, who was excellent and also offers tours of neighboring ruins by bicycle.  We highly recommend him.

As we drove towards Ritigala we were flagged down by a man wanting to be our guide he offered a good price, 1200rs, so we agreed and were very pleased with him.  He spoke good English, the children liked him, and we walked us round at a comfortable place and was happy to allow us to linger.  Heaps of history here that had been hidden by the jungle.  Lovely to see and imagine what it would have been like as a monastery. We had a really good visit and think it was well worth coming.

Beautiful ancient ruin in a very natural forest. Sort of off beaten track (it‚Äôs getting more popular nowadays). Inside Ritigala, there was very few people. Thoroughly enjoyed clam atomosoher in this beautiful ruins. There is a guide at the entrance, which was 10USD. I didn‚Äôt take it at the beginning and walked into the forest. However, there is no explanation apart from names only in Sinhala. After 10 mins, I saw another group having a guide, who I overheard explained things very well. So, I decided to go all way back to the entrance to get a guide. The verdict was mixed feelings. Apparently, only one guide there can speak English well enough to explain things and to have a conversation (answering questions), who was the one I saw. The one I got was just like a broken tape recorder. Only mentioning names of places, like ‚Äòkitchen‚Äô, ‚Äòtoilet‚Äô. He even passed a spot where I saw another guide was giving some explanation to his group. I made him stop and insisted to get some explanations even though most of the time, he just kept saying ‚Äòok, ok‚Äô.  In the end, it became sort of ok, but definitely not worth 10USD. He seemed to sense that I wasn‚Äôt really happy, then took me to some areas where a sign said ‚Äòdo not entre‚Äô. He showed me some ruins inside the forest off the main route. This part was very good. On the top of the route, I met the other ‚Äògood‚Äô guide again. He even asked me what I thought about my guide. When I said no good, he gave me a empathetic nod. (Basically he knows) When I paid, I didn‚Äôt have small rupees equivalent to10USD. So I had to round up and ended up paying him even tips, which he wouldn‚Äôt definitely be deserved. If you are lucky you can get a good guide, if not, go with some information about Ritigala. Without it, you would miss out a lot there.

We enjoyed our visit here, even in the rain!  You are free to walk up and around the forest site at your leisure.  We had a guide book with a reasonable amount of information about the site, without this we would have been lost as there are no information boards about what you are looking at and a pretty basic map at the entry lodge. The car park and visitor facilities are rudimentary, but functional. Worth a visit if you want to see an untouched, ancient site.

We enjoyed this place so much more than polonnaruwa - so much more relaxed, calm and much less busy. With it being in a forest, it is nice and shady too so much more comfortable walking around. Highly recommend exploring this place!

We drove for some twenty minutes on what could have been the quietest road in Sri Lanka and the road itself became more and more narrow.  We had not seen another vehicle in ages and I was at the point of wondering "where the hell are we?" when the road jungle opened up and suddenly we were in a carpark with several other cars and about eight big buses.  Hello, Ritigala. The site is a located in a beautiful piece of jungle, with ruined sites (foundations of ancient buildings) connected by roughly-hewn stairs.  It's a lovely walk, most uphill.  There is the most spectacular tree almost at the very top, don't miss it. You walk back down the same stairs to return to the carpark. Wear good walking shoes and take water.

We visited Ritigala in the afternoon. We were able to purchase the tickets, but we felt that we were tired and so decided to spend some time at the entrance and go back. Whilst we were driving back, we saw a huge elephant standing in our way. We stopped the car and waited as we had no other options except reversing back, but reversing all the way would have been extremely difficult as the road was not a smooth/straight one. But to our surprise, the elephant took its trunk and brought it up and down twice  (as though it was blessing us!!) and then went back into the jungle again. We waited for a bit longer to make sure that the elephant had gone inside the jungle and then drove back. This was one of the exciting moments of our trip in SriLanka.

Actual history of Ritigala leads into 5000 years or more which is linked into King Rawana. Since the inscriptions were purposely not read before 2500 years by our archeologist at that time. It is our history been hidden under the soil some reason.

One of a best archeological site in the country with lesser people if you go there only we can see old historical pride of Srilanka with amazing architecture values & old dynasty mix with Great Buddhism.

Visited Ritigala today and was very impressed. It is the remains of an old forest monastry. They are no Buddha statues, merely remnants of pillars and basement but well worth a visit. It is a pretty steep hike with most of the pathway laid with stone. There are however areas unlaid. Strongly suggest wearing sensible walking shoes and not flipflops like me. Also be mindful that as you under the forest canopy it gets extremely hot and humid.

Our family of five had a tour of Ritigala.  This was not as exhausting as Sigiriya.  A pleasant, easy walk with informative guide.  The children enjoyed learning about the legend of Ritigala and the guardian spirits of the mountain.
Off the beaten track but worth a visit. Wonderful local guide who was a wealth of information. Great viewing point from the library.

A little off the normal tourist track, and not that easy to get to.  We thoroughly enjoyed our visit here, it wouldn't have been quite as good without the excellent guide we had.  He was very enthusiastic and told us all about the monks and how they lived. I would recommend walking shoes, as at the beginning the path is uneven.  It's a lovely cool and quiet spot away from the main attractions. It used to be free, but now has a small charge - much less than the other government owned attractions.

Very easy walk. Cool as its in the rainforest. Tuk tuk is easy to get to from Habarana. Dont need guide. Cost us 310 rupees to get in and took photo of map. Was getting around for about 2 hours. Not too many tourists.

We went there in the afternoon as per hotel staff recommendation. It was a hot day but when we arrived climate changed massively, very cooler like a rain forest. Huge trees and lots of greenery. Nice walk up to the rock/mountain through ancient Buddhist monastery. Lots of old trees and some of them are very rare. Little water falls and beautiful nature, kids enjoyed a lot. The old ruins were great and surprised by the work, hospital, library and bridges. We have been warned by locals to take care of snakes and spiders. If you are lucky you can buy Wood-apple on the way.

Always looking for a slightly different experience to the main touristy things and this one is perfect.  Very interesting, picturesque and quiet.  We only passed one other tourist. It seems mainly Sri Lankans frequent this place, possibly for spiritual reasons.  If you are staying in the area it does not take long to get there and expect to spend no more than 90 minutes.  Basic facilities but you really dont need much else - it speaks for itself.  Minimal entrance fee.

A group of 18 of us visited Ritigala Ruins with ‚ÄúFlamingo Lanka Travels‚Äù on 10th December 2017.  This was my third visit to this fascinating mystical ruins.  These Ruins, open to the public, is within the ‚ÄòStrict Natural Reserve‚Äô that encompasses the larger Ritigala Mountain.  We purchased our tickets at the entrance.  The cost of a ticket is Rs 20 for locals (including residents) and Rs 500 for foreigners. The tour began with our tour leader visiting the Department of Archaeology site office to seek the services of a guide from the Department.  Starting from the Department offices we walked the first 100 metres of difficult terrain climbing up to ‚ÄúBanda Pokuna‚Äù (Built Pond).  The guide sat us down here and gave an introduction to the ruins and indicated on a map of the places we were to visit.  The ruins had been a monastery of a sect of Buddhist monks practicing extreme austerity wearing only robes made out of rags. Theirs was a life of meditation, seeking the ultimate truth, coming down from their caves only to accept food brought by visitors.  There had been a great deal of support for these monks from the ancient kings who built up this monastery for their use. This reservoir had been built in the 4th century bc and has a circumference of around 370 metres.  The inner surface is made up of steps using cleanly cut uniform stones (of about neatly cut 1000 x 30 x 15mm).  The top of the bund too is paved with similarly cut stones.  It is thought that the reservoir had been used by devotees who visited the temple. To get to the ruins we walked along the bund and across the stream that flows into this man made reservoir.  The walk across the stream is somewhat difficult as there are no built up steps.  However after we crossed the river and walked uphill we came to a neatly laid path, about 1.5 metre wide,  constructed using cleanly cut interlocking four sided rectangular stone slabs lined with kerbs on either side demonstrating excellent craftsmanship.  Even though our visit was around noon (between 1000 and 1300 hrs), the light along the path was soft and diffused from the overhanging branches of large trees.  The air itself was quite cool and comfortable.  The meandering stone paved path leads you to the many ruins scattered over an area of about 120 acres. Three circular platforms (roundabouts) called ‚ÄòGimanhala‚Äô built at locations along the way had been to provide rest to devotees while walking along the hilly pathway.  The guide took us off the main path to the ruins of a hospital (Janthagara) for monks with a sunken bath complete with grinding stones for preparing herbal medicines and a hearth that had been used to boil water and preparation of herbal concoctions.  We saw the ruins of a number of twin buildings with raised platforms enclosed within a courtyard, built atop a large boulder or rock foundation, joined with a stone bridge (Padhanagara).  One of these twin buildings is larger than the other and believed to have had a roof while the other was open.  There are also walking paths for meditation as well as the ruins of a library.  Bridges with stone slabs provide for crossing water streams.  Photos are attached with limited explanation.  Photos nor a description such as this can never do justice to what you see, feel and experience at the location. The guide showed us some stone slabs that had been drilled at a spacing of about 15 cm apart.  He explained that this had been the method used to split the rock.  The holes had been filled with a chemical or stuffed with material that would expand within the holes to split the rock.  The stones then were smoothed out using chisels or similar tools. Unlike at other Buddhist places of worship, there are no Buddha statues nor any decorations in any of the buildings demonstrating the beliefs and austerity of the monks who inhabited this monastery.  The only item with decorations was a urinal, perhaps demonstrating the aversion to decoration. The guide recounted a number of interesting legends related to these mountains.  This description is already too elaborate for me to recite these legends.  The visitor is encouraged to read about these at various internet forums as these depict the history and beliefs of the local people. It is a somewhat tiring walk.  Wear a pair of shoes with a good grip.  If you feel you are not up to go through the whole distance of about 3 km, you can stop in the shady undergrowth and sit on one of many stone structures.  Even if you see part of the forest and the ruins it is well worth your while!

Ritigala is situated 65 km from the ancient city of Anuradhapuara, and on the Anuradhapura - Habarana road through the Kandy-Jaffna Highway (A13 and A9) and 38 km from town of Habarana. Ritigala is a strict forest reserve and is known for its mountain range known as "Ritigala Kanda". Ritigala Kanda is the highest mountain in the Northern Region of Sri Lanka accounting for 766 m (2,513 feet) above sea level. Even though the reserve and the mountain is situated in the dry zone of Sri Lanka, the weather conditions at the peak of the mountain, and the vegetation of the mountain is completely different what you would see with the other peaks of the area. If one is interested in visiting the reserve then permission needs to be obtained from the Department of Wild Life in Sri Lanka. The legends say that the plants found in the peak of Ritigala Mountain range differ due to the fact that it is a part of mountain carried by Hanuman from Himayala during the battle of Ravana and Rama had dropped whilst flying over  the Ritigala range. In addition this legend the mountain range is well known for its Forest Monastery that dates back to 437 - 367 BC located in the Eastern side of the mountain range. Today the Monastery is in ruins, it is said that the monks who lived within the monastery did not mingle much with humans, and spent time building their spiritual life, with spending most of the time in meditation. Unlike most of the temples and monastery's in Sri Lanka, the monastery in Ritigala does not have any decorations or anything that depict beauty or happiness. The only point where something of beauty was seen was on the ground piece of a urinal,  and this is also to depict that the monks have let of all materialist things in life, by trampling them. The climb to the end of the monastery would take approximately 1 hours just to clime. But for someone who likes to snoop around well you have to be ready with plenty of time and water to drink. In addition to these Ritigala was known for the traditional martial arts form known as "Angam Poroa" which originated from the region, and legend says the the "Yodha" (Gian Worriors) a set of people how had super strength beyond a normal human being who served the kings who ruled the country spent time practicing the form of martial arts. It is further said, the one of the Yodha named "Ritigala Jayasena" who served King Dutugamunu, offended another giant warrior named Gotaimbara in a state of drunkenness. Finally they agree to a bare-hand dual. It is said that during the dual Gotaimbara decapitated Jayaseana with a single kick. Seeing the predicament deity offers to revive Jayasena before the corps go cold, and in the haste as they were unable to find the head of cuts off the head of bear, and fixes it to the body. Since there was much chaos, the head was fixed backwards. Even though Jayasena did get reviewed, people became horrified with the form now he was in and became ill every time someone came across Jayasena, and later he was known as "Mahasona". Apa

He turned out to be the most brilliant guide - full of facts and information about the ruins and beautiful, unusual trees, and able to describe in vivid detail how the community of monks would have lived, meditated and operated an ayurvedic hospital at Ritigala. When they came to establish Sri Lanka's first monastery there, the monks apparently brought plant species from the Himalayas and some of these still grow on the mountain, uniquely for SL. The road approaching Ritigala is stunning, and there were only a couple of other visitors when we were there. Our children, who experienced extreme temple fatigue at various other sites, loved Ritigala for its Indiana Jonesy atmosphere. It's an extraordinary place: 2000-year-old Ebony trees, rare types of monkey, an ancient library overlooking spectacular views, and an extremely well preserved system of walk ways, pools, and peaceful prayer places... well worth a visit. Give a donation - there's no ticket charge.

Revel in the majestic beauty of Sri Lanka‚Äôs wildlife when you travel to Habarana. Nestled in the heart of the cultural triangle, Habarana is the ideal base from which travellers can explore the glorious sights of Sri Lanka from the iconic rocky outcrop of Sigiriya to the Minneriya National Park, where more than 300 wild elephants gather on the shores of the reservoir, during the annual ‚ÄúElephant Gathering‚Äù. Minneriya National Park is one of the most popular attractions near Habarana, home to a collection of birds, reptiles, amphibians, butterflies and mammals such as sambar deer, buffalo, crocodiles and elephants. For those interested in a unique perspective of a quintessential Sri Lankan rural village, one can embark on a traditional bullock cart ride for a leisurely tour. Pass by lush green paddy fields, and catch a glimpse of the villagers as they go about their day. Adding to the charm of the excursion are sightings of the amazing birdlife, shrub forests, monkeys and other wildlife native to this area. For travellers who want to take in the sights and sounds of Polonnaruwa, Dambulla and Anuradhapura, it is ideal to stay in Habarana. Sightseeing holiday ideas when staying in Habarana include Dambulla Rock Temple, Hiriwadunna Park, Kaudulla National Park and Ritigala Forest Monastery.

This is a magical experience, the partial restoration tells stories and the mysteries still remain. It is almost unvisited which makes discovering it all the better. It is an extraordinary achievement to have built in stone such a complex which was home to so many. You can really appreciate how the jungle took over whilst it was abandoned, even some of the restoration is being encroached upon by the jungle. Find the library, it is a sublimely peaceful place with a breathtaking view. This is not a suitable visit for small children or the very unfit, but it was one of our best and most alone moments in Sri Lanka. If you do it without a guide then get some good information about it to understand it better. Also if you are self-driving as we were, be aware that your GPS may take you to the current Ritigala monastery, a fascinating place and not at all easily accessible. A lot of apologetic smiling and bowing later we found the ruins on the other side of the mountain.

I've read some people have mentioned that this place only has unimpressive ruins, few stones and just a few square blocks with no significance etc. Obviously if you do not do your research about this place you will think like that. The most amazing thing about Ritigala is how they have used rock to build this whole monastery where around 2000 enlightened beings used to live. The ruins you see is the whole complex which includes a complete path to access the monastery, stone bridges, ancient toilets, ponds, meditating area's, a library, walking meditation area's and a hospital. It's dates back to 1st century BC (some argue 5000 years ago during the Ravana kingdom). Another weird thing about this place is how this lush green area exists in the middle of a flat dry land (North Central Sri Lanka is very dry and no mountains). Also the climate at the summit is in sharp contrast to the climate at the foot; it is cooler in comparison to hot and dry climate of the region. The legend states Lord Hanuman of supernatural powers, traveled over Ritigala, and, by accident, dropped a chunk off a mountain of the Himalaya range he was carrying from India to Sri Lanka for its medicinal herbs. Lord Rama's brother, Prince Lakshmana was mortally wounded in battle and only a rare herb in the Himalaya could save his life. The pocket of vegetation of healing herbs and plants at the strange mini-plateau at the summit of Ritigala, which is distinct from the dry-zone flora of the lower slopes and surrounding plains at Ritigala, could thus be accounted for. It also states 'Yakkas' who apparently built this with their superhuman powers and they used special herbs to dissolve the stone in to liquid to build structures. Still archaeologists can't figure out how they managed to make such structures using only stone considering the limited technology they had. Whatever is true or not, this place is a must visit place if you are around Anuradhapura, Sigiriya. Very easy to travel and you will need about max 3-4 hours to cover the whole place. Go with an open mind and do your research. You will love it.

A new road makes access easier than it was a few years ago now a 15 minute tuk tuk ride from the main road. Entry is free, guide essential. With guide we rambled through the forest visiting the King's bathing pool, one of the monk's caves, a 3rd century BC toilet and a 1,000 year old tree amongst the ruins. We were there about 2.5 hours. Most interesting. Suggest you wear long trousers (a few mosquitoes) and stout footwear.
Really enjoyed climbing through the jungle to access Ritigala site - very beautiful and hardly anyone else.

I have visited Ritigala in few times. Ritigala is a mountain range ( consists of seven mountains) situated in dry zone of SriLanka. There is an archeology site situated at the base of the mountain. Ritigala was an ancient Buddhist hermitage. You can visit number of ruins well preserved by archeology department. This is the main tourist attraction of Ritigala. There is no entrance fee for forighners. Archeology site is situated 2km from main entrance of Ritigala and that road is mortable. There is an information center situated at the entrance of Ritigala, provides nice description about Ritigala. Most important thing of Ritigala is, it's biodiversity. As it is the highest place of Northern plane of Sri Lanka, it has different climate zone in the upper part. Some endemic plant species can be seen there and some of them are endemic to Ritigala. The area is strictly nature reserve and you can't visit beyond archeological site. The best months visit Ritigala is from February to Octomber. Other months you will get rain there. I was fortunate to visit the highest peak of Ritigala, it is called Kodigala and second highest peak- Urakanda.

This place just resonates peace and tranquility. The walk is picturesque and when you reach the top there is a beautiful little steam to cool your feet off in. Which is ideal because it is pretty hot and humid. One little warning, beware of the little leeches, wear insect repellant...
Lovely walk into the jungle. Great photo opportunities. Be careful it might rain.... History and Nature intertwined.....
The kids loved the rock stone steps leading to a water fall. Amazing place to see and imagine how all the rocks were moved  and placed leading to a temple all those years ago.

When I was in Cinnamon Lodge - Habarana just took a quick decision to visit this place. It is close by and the road is in average condition. Going through a small forest is a good experience. The officers of archaeological department office was so helpful. There may be various guides offering you help but all ruins are named and tagged which are self explanatory. In certain places, the steps are broken and slippery so be mindful. Worth watching even though hard to access certain places.

My advice  for all foreigners come and visit  free of cost. What a fantastic place to visit. If you  staying  habarana use tuk  tuk  options  1800 -2000  rupees for journey. From  sigiriya 2200-2500  ruppes. No entrance  tickets  fee but  you  can put  some donation  for environment  cleaning. Take enough  water  with  you  and used good shoe  if possible .

There are many steps to climb and as it is a historical place the steps and the pathway are hundreds or even over thousand years old! We visited it on a rainy day and because of the tree canopy it wasn't too bad but I suggest avoiding a wet day as the path at certain places was slippery.
I went here with my Sri Lankan friend and read a book at the old library until the sun went down. It's a magical place!

What an amazingly beautiful and serene spot in the middle of the forest. A long drive to get there but such a welcome  from the locals who had just finished serving lunch to the monks and offered us a meal.
There had been civilization before 3rd century BC and the architecture somewhat similar to Mayan concept..i have a doubt that Mayans had been here long years before
Nice, failry short walk in the jungle and interesting ruins. Easy to climb and lots of beautiful trees.

This was probably my favourite activity so far this trip. We went in the morning, by tuk tuk, and luckily we had the mountain to ourselves. The peace and serenity, only interupted by the sounds of the jungle, was so nice compared to the noise and hustle of tourists at the other ancient sites. If I was short of time, I would go here instead of Dambulla Rock, unless you are really interested in more statues of Buda. Gamini, out tuk tuk driver walked with us and explained some of the interesting features, as well as telling us about the different trees and creatures we encountered. It must have been a massive feat of engineering 1500 years ago to get the massive granite slabs up the mountain and in place. Great. P.S. free of charge, just a small donation required.;

A good place to wander around the ruins, bit of a hike, take lots of water. Not much about the history of the place though. I wouldn't go out your way to visit, but do if just passing. Free to go in, though a donation is asked for. Only wildlife we saw were loads of butterflies! And an elephant poo!

Amazing.  Ritigala has only recently opened for tourists, it is an ancient Buddhist monastery and the highest mountain in Northern Sri Lanka. The ruins and rock inscriptions date back to 1st century BC.  I recommend combining a trip to Ritigala with a stay at the Forest Rock Garden Hotel which is magnificent and won Green Hotel of the Year 2015

Ritigala is a Strict nature reserve. In this area having 366 buildings foundations. All these buildings had water supply. The tower and well where pump the the water to the tower now also you can see. There are granite pipes goes to the different ways. This is a monastery but really this mountain range belongs to the Yakka tribe. This could be a there war base. There are having a very big swimming pool. Water surface 1.2 Hectares and the depth is nearly 18 meters. Now it is under renovation. This is ancient worlds biggest swimming pool. There is a version, saying that This place bought a very rich person and made those buildings and presented to Buddha and his students. That means this may be a real Jethavanarama. That means where Buddha lives 40 years. Must has to see this place.

Although not as impressive as Sigirya, Ritigala is worth a visit ! This place used to be a Monastery where some monks, originally educated in Anuradhapura, established to help local people. Unfortunately, there is absolutely nothing to be found in English and this is a pretty remote area.

There is no entrence ticket, you just have to donate something, tuk - tuks from ritigala junction, which you can reach by bus are expensive - 1000LKRs for just 9km. The climbing takes 1-2hours, the forest is really nice and the paths are well kept.

We went by tuk tuk to Ritigala from Haberana with a great guy called Minda (probably spelt wrongly). Minda was an expert bird spotter and took us on a side trip to a lake where we saw an alligator, frogs, and eagles. We didn't bother with a guide at Ritigala, Minda came with us and pointed out various things of interest. The place is really atmospheric and although the buildings are in ruins, it is amazing to imagine the civilisation that created the monastery. On the way back we diverted to Habarana Lake where Minda showed us a monitor lizard - a great day out.
great place to visit, not a lot of tourists, you can hear and maybe see the monkeys and you see lots of abes. Remember to bring something to drink. The walk takes around 2 hours.

Great place to visit. Not many do it but it is worth the effort. You can now drive up to the site - apparently this was not possible before. You have to sign in (name ,passport details etc) for the site and a donation is requested. There are a lot of steps up to the top but there are lots of places to stop and see different parts of the temple. Some of the paths are through the forest which is good. The ancient monastery is inside a national park but we did not see any animals only monkeys though we did see elephant droppings.

We went here with a local guide, who, if you ignore the requests for doubling his fee due to a 'sick child', is a good guy. Our children (6 & 4) were fascinated by the stories of cobra houses, elephant attacks and special medicine trees. They were playing 'Tomb Raider', looking for clues to find the lost treasure (magic medicine) of the Buddhist monks who once lived in this beautiful forest location. Just make sure you stay on the trails

Ritigala consist an ancient Buddhist monastery and mountain in Sri Lanka. Amazing geography so unusual located in the dry zone. Still no proper directions to reach up to the mouton. At the peak that weather almost similar to central hill country. But still open up to the monastery and archaeological sight. some times need to use a hard drive car or a jeep to drive through humph road. Im only recommend this to people like to take feel the real trekking experience in this non residential forest with a better organization.
highly recommended if you are interested in Sri Lankan flora and fauna, early Buddhism or a pleasant but steamy 2-hour hike

I was expecting more of this place as I have read all the previous reviews. The place is in the middle of the forrest indeed, but there is really not much to see and the landscape is not breathtaking either. There are mostly conserved floor plans with some original stones... and lots of mosquitoes. You can see much more lush and green forrest with "Indiana Jones feel to it" in other parts of Sri Lanka (Pidurangala or Knuckles range for instance). Lonely planet description is also idyllic but don't get your hopes up. There is also one disinformation in the 2015 guide - there is no admission to this place. The guide says 10 USD. In fact you're only asked for a donation (so it's up to you how much you're willing to give). All in all it's a good place to kill some time but nothing really special. Personally I'd skip this place if I ever came back.

Very beautiful place not to overcrowded with people yet ,beautiful ruins and the forest ,hope the forest track from the main road will be preserved as it is and cutting of trees on the acses road will be stopped

Great place, nature and ruins are incredible, you can easily spent half a day exploring the ruins in the jungle ! (... in theory, you do not have to exit the patch. In theory...) Transport to this place is complicated, you can get closer but bus, but you will have to take a tuktuk for the last km.

Difficult to get to - We arrived with our driver at the faded and unused 'visitor centre' where we had to transfer to a tuk-tuk as the track was too muddy for vehicles. We came here as it sounded interesting in the lonely planet description but it wasn't that great. The part you can access (the rest is a protected area) has been part restored and there are some paths relaid. There is a fair bit of scrambling to do though which makes it more exciting but there is little to see here really and even the 'carved urinal' was a bit disappointing. Visit if you are passing but don't go out of your way.

We arranged to visit here with our tour guide, so was driven in a jeep there.  We visited on a Sunday and there was no one else there.  It is govt run and a donation is asked for, we gave 500 each, which was incredibly good value for money.  We spent around 2 hours wandering about, at a nice steady pace.  Some of it is uphill but not too taxing.  There is a tank, ruins, arches, a blood tree, queens toilet, executioners block - all in a jungle setting.  It is tranquil, you can hear the birds singing, waterfalls, frogs etc.  Lots of unusual rock formations and large trees.  The hills surrounding were swathed in clouds.  Lots of photo opps and by the time we had left we saw 3 other tourists.  Shame about the scabby dogs but they were everywhere in SL.  Would definitely recommend if you have time to visit.

We arrived after the monks had their meal and was offered food, but we declined. Loads of village people were coming in to enjoy a free meal. We walked up the 200 steps or I walked up the path which ran next to the steps. At the top in this forest setting was a peacful stupa area. You can just sit or do a meditation in this tranquil setting.
Must visit. Lovely countryside. You have to see visit as to see the true nature of Sri Lanka. It is very important if you a Buddhist too.

It took us a 20 minute tuktuk drive from the mainroad for 1500 rupees. The sandy road was not accessable for regular cars because of rain in recent past. After arival at the entrence, you can climb all the way to the old library. The climb is avarage but not easy at some parts. It is a very nice and peacefull place. No tourists. No entrance fee. You can make a donation if you want. I paid 1000 for two persons and 500 as a tip to the guide who took us up, who also didn't charge anything, but was very friendly. We went up and down within the hour. Although old ruins, the place is beautifull. The nature around it as well. If you have time besides Sigiriya rock, Aduarapura and the Dambulla caves, I would highly recommend!
Amazing atmospheric temple complex, buried into some truly deep jungle, get a local Tuk Tuk driver to take you there.

You'll have to conquer a bit of bad road to get there. Our visit however was quite nice. It's a short track, climbing smoothly and it's a nice place in general. According to our travel book, in the past you could climb to the top and there was an entrance fee, but this is old information as you are not allowed anymore to climb further into the jungle. Visit is free and you are expected to give something. The guy at the entrance did not seem that happy with our 1000 rupees, although in my opinion it's enough.

As others have said, Ritigala does have a bit of an Indiana Jones feel to it, although pretty much all that's left is the foundations of buildings and walk paths. I was the first one there in the morning (at 9am), so I had the whole place free to myself to walk around. A couple of groups came after me, but I only saw them on the way out. I was able to get a tuk tuk driver to take me there and back for 1,000 LKR, which also included him walking me around the site. The staff informed me right away that it was a donation to enter, and did not try to trick me into paying anything as others experienced. I spent a couple of hours there, and really enjoyed it. I would definitely recommend it for anyone who is interested in getting away from the crowds for a bit and seeing some decent ruins and massive trees.

Practical info: you can GET HERE from Habarana by bus, get off at Ritigala. You will see a sing pointing the direction to the ruins. According to tthe sign it's 9 km. Away. That's why there will be tuk tuk drivers waiting there. They want 1500 LKR (after Bargaining) two ways. The only thing is that They want you to do the treck in an hour while you can easily spend 3 hours there. The ENTRANCE FEE is an obligatory donation, you will pay it in a small office at the entrance . Don't let the tuk tuk driver see how much you donate. After that you can enjoy yourself exploring the area. Don't be afraid to leave the path and explore also sideways. That's how we found a lookout called the Fort. A nice place to have breakfast. If you sit there for some time you will see rare birds which come there to drink water. When you will get to the top of the path after seeing a few ruins you will see the sign of a restricted reserve area. Big rare langurs live there. They are called "bear monkeys". We were able to See two of them close to the border of their area. Don't forget to bring mosquito repellent.
It's a beautiful place and an easy climb. It's almost as if you're climbing through a jungle. Loved it.

Having been intrigued by pictures of this place we decided to make the trip out here to see the ruins.  We took a bus bound for Anuradhapura and got off at the Ritigala Junction.  From there we took a tuk-tuk.  This felt like a rip-off as the driver ended up charging us 1300 rs.  I could tell we were paying a good rate as he was smiling for the whole trip.  Anyhow once you start up the trail to the ruins you will forget about any tuk-tuk negotiations.  At the site we were told there was an entrance fee of (I want to say) 1300 rs. each, which we balked at.  We were then asked to make a donation of 500 rs. each which seemed more reasonable. There was no one else on the trails and we had plenty of time to explore the various ruins.  There were small offshoots at some of the trails where there were some significant additional ruins.  Make sure you've got an hour or two to explore everything.  Highly recommended if you are down with photography.

While the climb was a bit gruelling in the heat, Ritigala was well worth it. We chanced upon a guide, which was a good thing, as he could tell us what each ruin was. The water tank and stairs are remarkably well-preserved. Be sure to wear good shoes and carry mosquito repellent.

This has been one of our top experiences. It's a 45 min tuk tuk ride from Habarana and is a peaceful, natural place for meditation, exploration and quiet contemplation. Walking up a series of magnificently constructed walkways you encounter various architectural wonders which have been mysteriously constructed amid the forest. The trees themselves leave you in little doubt as to why Sri Lankans apparently used to worship them. Walking in the forest and the trip to and from the site gave us some wildlife encounters - a mongoose, monkeys, deer, the greeter coucal bird, an eagle hawk, chameleons and lizards. And we had the site to ourselves - it was spectacular.

Great jungle ruins, quiet with few visitors adding to the experience as monkeys scream in the tree tops, and lizards scuttle across the ruins.  A bit too dry to feel really Indiana Jones, children had been hoping for king Louis from the jungle book!  But they still described it as awesome. Entrance was donations, no guide pushed on us so we were free to wander for a couple of hours. Amazing granite blocks, how did they do it?  Worth detouring of the paved path to find the lookout fort, which was the highlight for us. Very basic toilets.  Take water.

Ritigala is one of the greatest forest monasteries I have visited in Sri lanka. The wonderful constructions using solid granite stones , ponds, ruins of building foundations stairways made of solid granite are mesmerizing. Presently we have difficulty in shaping up a single granite stone to turn out a stepping stone but just imagine how our ancestors have shaped up them and placed hundreds of such stone steps to make a an excellent pathway at a period where such advanced technologies were not available. Or were their more advanced technologies available in the past? The history says that this had been a monastery where the ancient kings who governed the country in the 16th or the 17th century had created, for thousands of monks to live and follow their religious rituals. However the ancient stories carry tales to say that certain tribes called yaksha" had been making this great mountain as their kingdom. his mountain which is covered with a range of mountains around it is excellently rich with rare trees fauna and flora. If you are genuinely interested to explore the past , it will need at least a day with a guide to study the valuable facts connected to this world heritage site.

Ritigala is a nice site, quite different from Polonawura and Adurnarhupa. The site is in the jungle, with a few temple ruins to visit, and deserves a trip if you're around. However, the site should should be free, but the people of archeological department asked us to pay 10$/person to come in (of course without any receipt...). Our guide even went at the end to take his commission.

Went to Pidurangala rock and Ritigala ruins by tuc tuc from Habarana, was a nice trip. The forest was nice, some big impressive trees making for nice photos, not many or really amazing ruins, there is no official entrance fee, leave a donation at your own discretion. Nice walk, worth the hour or so stop if you go to Lion Rock or Pidurangala rock.

Between Habarana junction and Maradankadawala Junction On Anuradapura - Polonnaruwa road you get Ritigala forest monastery. According to my personal belief that is the best place to learn and practice spirituality. Very calm and quite place.

Teaching staff of our school arranged a field trip to ritigala.Actually it was worthy to be there to experience the nature of an undisturbed forest. Students had a nice time.they got solved their questions and doubtful matters. Though it' s somewhat weary Things that students gained are priceless. The project officer of forest dpmt did a good job in coordinating the people Maradankadawala secondary school.

The ruins are not particularly breat taking, but it was enjoyable walk through the jungle. I also foun the ruins intriguing even though they were not very massive or spectacular. There were only a couple of tourists so itwas possible to explore the ruins in peace and silence and spot lizards and monkeys. Felt a little like Indiana Jones :). It was very clean, no trash around. There is no admission fee but a donation is expected, we donated 1000 rupees each.
This was a lovely - if somewhat demanding - climb through the jungle to see ancient monastic ruins. Very enjoyable however, with knowledgable guide.

This was a great walk up through rainforest to ancient Buddhist monastic ruins. The forest was lovely and we got to see plenty of wildlife. The walk up is reasonably strenuous but worth the effort. The ruins themselves are not extensive and there is a lot to see but they are very interesting in their own right.

On reading some of the reviews of Ritigala on TripAdvisor, I was expecting some kind of Indiana Jones-esque ancient ruin in the jungle.  It's not. As we had already used half a day in a Sigiriya visit, my partner and I decided to take a trip to nearby Ritigala during our final day in the Habarana area.  Our driver took us as far as he dared and we then clambered aboard the the tuk tuk that had followed us from Habarana (on reflection, we should have just got the tuk tuk from there).   After a short ride along a bumpy dirt track, we arrived at a few scruffy buildings and were ushered inside one to sign the visitor book and also pay the 'donation' fee of 500Rs each.   can't complain about the 500Rs as that is pretty much pocket change to most westerners.  From there we were offered a tour guide to which we declined as we preferred just to explore ourselves. The ruins are not impressive at all - they don't seem particularly ancient.  If you've been anywhere there are some impressive ruins  - e.g. Pompeii, Athens or Latin America, you might even walk past the Ritigala ruins assuming that the real ruins are further on.  Well, they aren't.   When you reach a point where there's a square with some old building foundations, the rest of the path is blocked off - apparently it's because of the risk from dangerous wildlife (snakes, scorpions etc)..   I'd actually have been quite interested in seeing some of those but safety first, I suppose. On the positive side, it's a reasonably pleasant walk in the forest with all the Sri Lanka forest noises that you'd expect - we didn't see much in the way of wildlife -  a few interesting bright red bugs and a couple of monkeys in the trees but it's more of a walk in the park than a walk on the wild side. Truthfully, I'd skip Ritigala unless you have a lot of time to kill and have run out of other things to do. + Fairly secluded/not very busy + free/donation + pleasant forest walk - ruins distinctly unimpressive - top is blocked off

after sigiriya and polonnaruwa visit. on the way to anuradhapura, very nice place to visit. i prefer good to visit in the evening. but should better rent a jeep from Habarana. should not get a tuk tuk from the junction to the Ritigala. also near at the wildlife department office can rent a jeep. but there is few buggers around. last time i went their with my friend from australia, an old guy offered me to take my friend to Ritigala by his foot cycle and guide her. so better to rent a jeep from habarana, jeep drivers know every things.

This is very beautiful. There is a small parade of huts before entering the park. Do take time to have a drink called "orange" even though it is green. Really refreshing. The park is beautiful with a very old Buddha stature. Be respectful and cover your shoulders and legs from the knees up when entering the park.

Nice walk and interesting remains of old monastery .  The road there is in very bad condition making it difficult for cars. Tuk tuk drivers offer trips to the site. They charge 1500 rupees.  The driver we ad ave a very good tour for tge price and was very knowledgeable about the area.

Well worth the walk up to the site. Our car couldn't drive the last 2km, so we walked, not after been warned to be very carefully, staying on the track and turning back immediately should we meet wild elephants. Well we did not them and arrived at the site which is completely forlorn in the jungle. I've never seen trees of this size and age - it's simply amazing. Even the tiny rests of the monastery are impressive. A visit absolutely to do if you are near!

Don't expect mayor ruins or heavily restored temples, but, as one guide book described it, it is a bit of an Indiana Jones experience. I loved the fact that we were the only visitors and the fact that it is a nice walk through a lush forest. The site itself is fairly small and one can cover it easily in 1 hour. Despite what some guide books say, entrance is free. The only negative thing is that, should you have a driver, he will likely refuse to drive the  last 1.5km of dirt road. The only tuktuk driver around demands Rs 1300, which is far too much. You can even walk there really. Recommended

Definitely go in the morning as later in the day the peace and tranquility is ruined by noisy groups of locals. As others have mentioned, the road to the entrance is bumpy and probably even inaccessible by most means of transportation after heavy rains. We went by tuk tuk (1000 rupees from Habarana) and it was fine. There's a bit of a scam happening with the "entrance fee". Our tuk tuk driver said it was free, Lonely Planet said it cost USD $10 but upon arrival the guy behind the desk said it was a "donation" of 500 rupees p.p.  We asked him for an official price list and receipt. He couldn't provide either, so he let us in for free. By the way, there is a "donation box" before the entrance to the path. As far as I'm concerned, a donation is supposed to be voluntary.  Anyway, the path is for the most part clear and easy to walk and follow. You should count on a couple of hours roundtrip. We saw shy bear monkeys and enjoyed the ruins as they do give a sense of mystery.

Set deep in the forest, a very peaceful place.  We went early morning arriving 8.30 and were the first visitors of the day.  We got a real sense of the peace and tranquility of the place  helped by our excellent driver and guide.  Even with the rough guide, we felt it was very helpful to have a guide to lead us around. A truly magical place

This is seldom visited but is real forest scrambling up a clear trail across huge boulders beside a stream to a hidden ruined monastery. Beautiful, trees were full of monkeys telling us to go away crashing through the branches. magical. So glad we added it to our itinerary.

Went here yesterday. Jeep ride to the entrance was fun. Cool breeze a relief. The site is  Truly beautiful and amazing in terms of the ruins, the history and the jungle setting. The view from the monk library was fantastic too. Walk is totally do able and worth it.

This is situated at the Anuradhapura Habarana road near to Habarana Town. One has to travel about 6km  off the main road to the bottom of the mountain. Last two km of the road is in the Strict Natural reserve and is a gravel road. In the monsoon or after it is bit difficult for a car to travel. It is best that you get a local guide for your assistance. Near the vehicle park there is a office where one has to give the details of the travelling people. The climb is about 500m. Not very difficult fully worth the effort. Take some water or soft drink but do not litter.At the Ayurveda hospital site I noticed a "Grease Trap" you find in modern hotel installations to separate oil from water before sending out. This was at the drain path of the "Oil Bath" of the hospital. Certainly the WOW factor is there.

You have to drive on a lonely, rough route for around 30 minuted to enter ritigala but it is worth the drive. As the driving path falls across a jungle better to travel at early morning (We went around 9 AM). The place is wonderful with lot of ruins which are the remainings from a great architectural history of ancient Sri Lanka. We felt amazed after seeing the ruins of monestry, ponds and castles etc. The local guides at the office said there are Bears and wild animals in the jungle so not advised to travel at evening. Better travel with a group as you go through the jungle. There is no entry fee but it is expected to donate any amount after visiting the forest.
Ancient monastery around 30 min walking from the parking lot in the jungle,spotting termiten,kameleons,eagles and huge beautiful trees..

He may says wrong information. This is very nice, very important, very attractive place. Here is a URL for get more information about this place: http://www.srilankaview.com/ritigala.htm

A ruined monastery in the middle of nowhere. Well worth the trek, not another western tourist to be found. I fell for the "reduced" entrance price thing. More fool me, however my tuk tuk driver didn't let me fall for the guide scam. He asked for 2500rps but my driver gave him 200. The place was amazing.

My mum's been wanting to visit the Ritigala Monastery for a quite awhile now and finally, on one of our many trips to see the usual Cultural Triangle sites (e.g. Sigiriya), we decided to visit Ritigala. I highly recommend it to everyone; it's kind of in the middle of nowhere but that promotes its peaceful factor. It is a site to be seen and experienced with your eyes, ears and heart. My mum and I walked through the paved stone path and among tree roots in total silence, breathing in the fresh air and keeping a reflective mindset. For the short time we spent there, we forgot all about the hustle and bustle of city life and other such materialism. A wonderful part of Sri Lankan heritage and well-worth a visit. The only sour note for us were the pesky bureaucratic "officials" who were in charge of the place - they pestered us for money for a personal tour and offered a cheaper entry ticket - but stand your ground and stay firm in your refusal. Once you leave behind the entrance, you will soon forget about bureaucracy and everything else and just only be entranced by nature!

Our visit to Ritigala was an off the cuff decision based on the fact we read about it in the rough guide and it was near to us. What a great decision it was - a highlight of our short tour of SL. The nature reserve is 5km up a very bumpy, muddy and pot holed track. There were only four other tourists there and the hour or so walk through the jungle to view the ruins was exceptional. You'll need to hire a guide to show you where to go (R1000) and the entrance seems to depend on what the manager wants you to pay. It said R500 in the guide, but we had to pay R1000... That said, it was a beautiful, tranquil treat to wander through the jungle. My wife and I loved it. Head away from the crowd and go here. We enjoyed this much more than some of the other more well known attractions.
Very peaceful,but it is in the middle of nowhere in fact we go lost trying to find it!It was worth the journey .Sitting by the pool enjoying the site

The approach road gets flooded and really bad during the rainy season so check with our hotel if its possible to go. Take drinking water with you and wear good walking shoes.
