This is one of the loveliest and most atmospheric places I have ever been to. There are miles of ancient stone paths and steps though the forest, some of which have been restored. There are ruined refectories and enigmatic 'roundabouts' (apparently for walking meditation). The trees and wildlife are beautiful and there is the sound of waterfalls all around you. It's quite cool, but like many sites in Sri Lanka involves many hundred rock steps and a bit of a scramble at times. The atmosphere is out of this world. It is not visited all that much, which adds to its charm. It's on a rough track from the main road (our driver booked a jeep). When we got to the ticket office, still several kilometres from the entrance, a huge tree had fallen across the road and nothing had been done about it (it falls between the Forestry Department and another), so we paid a local lad to take us down the track on his motorbike! Clouds of butterflies rose up as we went along the track and I heard load roaring and crashing noises from the forest (wild elephants). There was birdsong everywhere.

We decided to go to Ritigala only 14 km from Habarabana to try to get a bit of the beaten track. It was very much a success. The park is an old monastery with surprisingly well conserved ruins. Tourists have obviously not truly spotted this place (yet!) and the artefacts are not covered in glas etc. but appears to be as they were left by the monks a few thousand years ago. At the entrance about 2 km from the actual park there is a visitor centre which is quickly overseen. We did not see any official staff but were met by 3-4 men with a jeep who adviced us that an ordinary car could not make it the last 2km to the park as the road was damaged. Instead they proposed to take us by jeep and give us a tour for 4000 rupees. We took it for a scam (of which there are many in Sri Lanka) but when we decided to walk the last bit one of them insisted on following us at least to park. To make a long story short the truth was that the road WAS impassable by ordinary car and the elephant danger was in fact very real. The elephant stories were later validated by pictures and other locals. As elephants are present all year nobody should try to walk, but in dry seasons (we visited in January) any car can do the trip. We ended up asking the "guide" to follow with us the entire trip which was a good decision as - his poor English aside - was very knowlegable about the site and show us stuff we would never have found by ourselves. The trip includes a approx 4km hike up a mountain side (medium intensity) and lasts about 2-3hours. There is an entrance fee of 1500 rupees pr person (be aware that the staff might try to persuade you to a lower price which they will then keep to them selves - if possible pay full and ask for a receipt). After the trip the guide was so nice as to invite us for lunch with his family. Best experience so far! He lives in a small house on the corner right in front of the visitor centre. If you pass by and want a guide be sure to ask him.
Lost in a forest, you'll need a 4x4 -or in our case a Tuktuk - to get down the road here, but it's worth it to find one of the most armospheric ruins in Sril Lanka tucked into the hillside jungle

Allow plenty of time to visit this site (1/2 day) as if you rush there and back you will miss the wildlife and atmosphere of this remote place. Look out for peacocks on the surfaced access road. When we went (early Nov 2012) the last track (unsurfaced) was badly rutted and it was tricky getting to the car park in our hired car.  We arrived mid afternoon and the custodians had "run out of tickets" - so we paid nothing. You don't need a guide - just follow the main path and use the guides available on the internet. But we had someone to help spot the abundant wild life and plants - that was very good. As others have said it is a bit of a clamber round the old tank and up the slope on the opposite side of the stream - but after that it is a well made (original) pathway to the top.

We made the mistake of walking the 6 km from the main road - don't.  Take a tuk-tuk!  The "officials" at the site offered to give us access at less than the official ticket price - and pocketing the money themselves.  I would strongly advise that you pay the official price and get an official ticket - that way there is some chance that the site is looked after.  I would also recommend that you get a guide.  Ours was not expensive - R500 and did not speak that much English, but he did show us a lot of places we would not have found by walking on our own.  He was also able to communicate some of what the various places were. The real joy of the place is the vast array of mostly unrestored ruins and the pathways between them.  Ritigala is not a major attraction and is all the better for it. Exploring the ruins amongst the forest is a great experience and for me one of the best!

A step back in time. This was a wonderful place to wander around and see what ruins you can find in the woods. Some wonderful viewpoints, and sitting quietly listening to the sounds of the forest, contemplating life here as a monk many centuries ago, was fantastic.

This is the site of an ancient monastery and hospital from around 300BC. When we arrived, the govt. representative sitting in what looked like a very bad office suggested that we needed cultural package tickets that were only available in Colombo! He then let us know that for about $10, he would let the six of us visit. Not knowing the language and the rules very well, we paid him - leaving me feeling great about the awesome deal as well as a bit dirty for bribing the guy. He also offered to give us a tour for another $10. WTH, why not. We really enjoyed the brief tour he gave - and thought that without his info, we wouldn't have appreciated the site for what it was. Enjoy the weather because this place has its own micro-climate. It is quite a thrill to sit there among the huge stone structures and contemplate a functioning monastery from 2000 years ago. While officially prohibited, were were told that you can go past the last major structure, further up the mountain and enjoy the scenery, climate and natural life around. Worth the short trip from Habarana. Don't miss it.

First of all, it's not at Habarana. In fact it's about 15 miles away and you you will definately need your own transport to get there. The authorities appear to be constructing a visitor centre at the site, so it is possible that there may be some sort of transport service from the main road at some point, but at present, 2010, it's a bumpy 5 mile ride down a dirt track. The site itself is like nothing else I've found in Sri Lanka. No statues, stupas, living quarters, or any of the other things you find in religious sites elsewhere. On arrival, someone will take your money, or Cultural Triangle ticket, and warn you about bears in the forest. Then you are directed up a dirt / mud track which brings you to one end of the tank that served as a water source. From there you need to pick your way along a narrow path through the trees for about 100 yards before reaching a set of steps. This is not a disabled-friendly place. The monastary itself consists of a series of clearings connected by granite tracks. The clearings contain ruins but no one really seems to know what most of them were for. Ritigala does not seem to be on the usual tourist itinery, there were several groups of Sri Lankans visiting while we were there, but we were the only westerners. Make a point of going if you can.
